msIdentifier.repository: Perne Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

summary.seg: Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 95 (hereafter Peterhouse 95) is a composite manuscript of two unequally sized Parts. The first and larger part (ff. i-vii, 1-120) is largely comprised of popular medical treatises in Latin, and the second and smaller part contains a glossed copy of Guillaume de Mandagout's De electionibus in Latin. Both Parts of the manuscript were together by 1501 at the latest, since Thomas Deynman Deynman, Thomas, fl. c. 1473, d. 1501 (d. 1501), a former Master of Peterhouse added his name to leaves in both Parts.

Before passing into Deynman's care, Peterhouse 95 was once owned or used by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) , a doctor and physician to Edward IV. In common with numerous other manuscripts, Marchall added a table of contents to the beginning of the manuscript (f. iii verso) as well as rubrics and running headings for some of the treatises in the volume (see e.g., f. 1r). Marchall's ownership or use of manuscripts is very well-attested, with forty-five surviving books (including this one) bearing evidence to connect him to them in some way; six others may have been his or accessed by him, and a further twelve are recorded but not traced. Thirteen manuscripts owned or used by Marchall (and another with possible Marchall connections) have been digitised, catalogued and conserved as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project:
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 59/153 (Voigts 1995, no. 2)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 98/50 (Voigts 1995, no. 4)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57 (Voigts 1995, no. 5)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 159/209 (Voigts 1995, no. 9)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 178/211 (Voigts 1995, no. 10)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 181/214 (Voigts 1995, no. 11)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 345/620 (Voigts 1995, no. 12)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 373/593 (Voigts 1995, no. 13)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599 (Voigts 1995, no. 14)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623 (Voigts 1995, no. 16)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 95 (Voigts 1995, no. 24)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 222 (Voigts 1995, no. 28)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.31 (Voigts 1995, no. 29)
Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9213 (possible Marchall connections) (Voigts 1995, no. 48)

Peterhouse 95 contains several popular medieval medical treatises including the Liber aggregationum of Serapion the Younger in the Latin translation by Simon of Genoa and Abraham of Tortosa, the Areolae of Iohannes de Sancto Amando, and the De simplicibus medicinis of Yuhanna ibn Masawaih (Mesue). Examination of the copy of the De simplicibus medicinis in the manuscript reveals two unusual codicological features. First, the production of Quire 9 (ff. 80-91) appears to have been completed with some difficulty; some text is struck through at the end of f. 83v, the following leaf was cancelled, and a singleton was added, not, as is typical, in the position of the cancelled leaf, but one leaf after (i.e., the singleton is f. 85 not f. 84), and there are further deletions and corrections on ff. 86-87. As it now stands, the text in that quire (Mesue's De simplicibus medicinis) is correct, but the scribes responsible for producing this part of Peterhouse 95 appear to have performed some very precise codicological surgery in order to fix their copy of the De simplicibus medicinis while also retaining as much of their existing work as possible. Secondly, a large number of leaves have been lost between the leaves now designated ff. 98v and 99r. There are 12 stubs present in the gutter between ff. 98v-99r; these stubs are probably what remains of the last three leaves of Quire 10 and the first nine leaves of Quire 11. The text at the end of f. 98v is the last part of Mesue's De simplicibus medicinis) in this manuscript, and it ends abruptly in the middle of a sentence. The number of stubs present in the gutter suggests that some further text-leaves have been lost from Peterhouse 95, as the only remaining leaf of Quire 11, f. 99, is blank, and it is unlikely that Quire 11 would have been placed in the manuscript if it were entirely blank.

References: L. E. Voigts, âA Doctor and His Books: The Manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)â, in New Science out of Old Books: Studies in Manuscripts and Early Printed Books in Honour of A.I. Doyle, ed. by R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (Aldershot: Scolar Press, 1995), pp. 249â314

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

foliation.p: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto. The right pastedown in the manuscript has the designation '128' (recto) and is referred to as such throughout this catalogue record.

collation.formula: 18-1 (1st leaf missing) ; 2-712 88-1 (8th leaf excised); 912 1010-3 (8th-10th leaves missing) 1110-9 (1st-9th leaves missing or excised) ; 1212 (ff. 100-111) 136-1 (6th leaf missing) 144 | 158(last leaf is now the right pastedown)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.

The quires have alphabetic designations (a-i k-n) in pencil in a 20th century hand. The quire designations in this sequence are written in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire; the first quire (ff. i-vii) is unmarked, and the alphabetical designation sequence begins with an 'a' at Quire 2 and concludes with an 'n' at Quire 15. The loss of the majority of Quire 11 is not distinguished by this sequence as the sole remaining leaf of that quire is treated as the final leaf of Quire 10.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords common to the entire volume.

binding.p: 18th-century binding. Undecorated parchment cover over thin pasteboards. Five raised bands on spine. Description of the contents of the volume written in ink on the spine in an 18th century hand. The number '100' (a former catalogue number for this item) in ink on the spine. Small printed paper label fixed to the spine with an adhesive bearing the shelfmark designation '95'. Parchment pastedowns; the right pastedown is the final leaf of the final quire.
Traces of a former title in light brown ink along the upper perimeter of the left cover. Traces of a title on the tail edge of the bookblock, now too rubbed to be legible.

The left pastedown contains:
A note, 'James 206' in ink - this refers to the catalogue number for this item in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600).
A note, 'M. James 95' in pencil - this refers to catalogue number for this manuscript in A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Peterhouse (1899) by M. R. James.
A note in ink in the hand of Thomas Deynman Thomas Deynman (fl. 1473-d. 1501), Bachelor of Medicine and Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. 1473-d. 1501 : see Provenance for further information.
A short aphorism in ink (also on ff. 105v-106r in a ?16th century hand: 'Suche is ffortune
In space ys grace
In grace ys goodnes

provenance.p: Owned by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall -1477 . List of the contents of the volume in Marchall's hand on f. iii verso, and titles to text added in his hand on ff. 1r, 78r, and 102r. Voigts suggests that the medical recipe in the right-hand column of f. 120v may be in Marchall's hand, but the hand appears to be closer to that of Thomas' Deynman rather than Marchall insofar as it represents the scribal activity of an identifiable scribe.

listBibl.bibl: L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314. Peterhouse MS 95 is no. '24' in Voigts' inventory of manuscripts associated with Marchall.

provenance.p:
Owned by Thomas Deynman (fl. 1473-d. 1501), Bachelor of Medicine and Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. 1473-d. 1501 who wrote his name in several places:
On the left pastedown: '... Thome Deynman medico'
iii verso: over an erasure 'Thome Deynman medicus'
In the upper margin of f. 1r after Marchall's title to the text: 'Thome deynman medici'
On f. 76r: 'Thome Deynman medici'
On f. 77v: 'liber Thome Deynman medici'
On f. 120v: 'Constat Thome Deynman medici'
On f. 128r (right pastedown): 'Thomas Deyman medicii'

history.acquisition: When and how Peterhouse MS 95 came into the possession of the College library is not entirely clear; the volume probably passed into the College library collection in the 1470s (before 1477) through a donation by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall -1477 . Marchall was a doctor and manuscript collector, and was a royal physician to Edward IV; his annotations appear in several places in Peterhouse MS 95. Marchall gave several scientific and medical manuscripts to Peterhouse in 1472; the list of Marchall's donations is now preserved with the general inventory of books belonging to the College in a document known as the Registrum vetus ('The Old Register'). The record of Marchall's donations is in his own hand and is on a separate leaf sewn into the Registrum vetus. Marchall's donation document has the heading Billa magistri Roberti Marchall de dono suo scripta propria manu suo anno domini Millesimo 1472 and is printed as UC48.385-396 in CMBLC 10. Marchall's donation document names or describes 12 books, none of them a good match for Peterhouse MS 95; three of Marchall's donations still belong to the College, but others now belong to other institutions or have been lost. Even though Peterhouse MS 95 is not one of the books included in Marchall's donation list, Marchall owned a substantial number of scientific and medical manuscripts and could have chosen to give the volume to Peterhouse at another time rather than as a part of the 1472 gift. The Corpus of British Medieval Library Catalogues suggests that Peterhouse MS 95 may have been left to the College as part of a bequest by Master of the College, Thomas Deynman, c. 1501. Like Marchall, Thomas Deynman (fl. c. 1473, d. 1501), Bachelor of Medicine and Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. c. 1473, d. 1501 was also a doctor and royal physician (in Deynman's case he seems to be associated with Kings Edward IV, Henry VII and Lady Margaret Beaufort), and was a Fellow of Peterhouse before becoming its Master for a shortlived tenure c. 1500-1501. Deynman added ownership inscriptions in several places in the volume, but whether he gave the book having obtained it personally from Marchall, or whether it was simply in the Peterhouse Library and he took it into his personal possession during his association with the College is unclear. In his will, Deynman left 20 of his better books (his 'uolumina meliora') to Peterhouse, and so it is possible that if Deynman had taken personal possession of Peterhouse MS 95 then it may have passed back into the general holdings of the College's library collection upon his death. Much of the information above derives directly from L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314. Peterhouse MS 95 is no. '24' in Voigts' inventory of manuscripts associated with Marchall. See also CBMLC 10 - UC48.385-396 and pp. 687-688, 718

recordHist.source:
This catalogue entry draws substantially on R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Woodbridge, 2016). Readers of this record are strongly encouraged to consult Thomson's Catalogue for further information. This catalogue entry also draws on:
M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Peterhouse (Cambridge, 1899)
CBMLC 10
Unpublished notes made by Dr Debby Banham in 1999 and 2000 as part of a survey of medical manuscripts in Cambridge

availability.p: Researchers should note that Peterhouse's western European medieval manuscripts are housed at Cambridge University Library (CUL). Scholars who wish to consult Peterhouse manuscripts should contact the Manuscripts Reading Room at CUL to arrange their visit; all CUL admissions procedures will apply. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library. For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for itching
msItem.note: Medical recipe to help with itching in the hand of Thomas Deynman (fl. c. 1473, d. 1501), Bachelor of Medicine and Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. c. 1473, d. 1501 .

msItem.title: Le livre dou tresor [Old French] 2.62-2.67
msItem.author: Brunetto Latini, 1220â1295
msItem.incipit: i recto Tout auant que tu dies mout tu dois considerer en ton cuer que tu es qui uiues parler
msItem.explicit: iii recto la chose deuant ce que on le dioit

listBibl.bibl: Edition of the text: F. J. Carmody (ed.), Brunetto Latini, Li Livres dou Tresor (Berkeley, 1948)

msItem.title: Distinctio ponderum et mensuraram
msItem.author: Arnaldus de Villanova (d. 1311)
msItem.rubric: iii recto Distinctio ponderum et mensurarum Magistri Arnaldi de Villa noua secundum Serapionem Auicennam et alios auctores in medicina
msItem.incipit: iii recto Kirath uel kirathes secundum Auicennamet Serapionem est pondus
msItem.explicit: iii verso Chise uidetur esse mensura continens sub .i. uini
msItem.note: Thomson notes that this text is also in Salins-les-Bains, BibliothÃ¨que municipale, MS 45 (P.38), ff. 376r-379r

msItem.title: List of the contents of Peterhouse MS 95
msItem.author: Roger Marchall
msItem.note: Below the list of the contents of the volume is an erased ownership inscription; the final part of the inscription can still be read as 's. 16. d. 8.', probably a price paid for the volume.

msItem.title: De dosibus medicinarum
msItem.author: Walter Agilon (fl. 13th century)
msItem.incipit: iv recto Dosis medicinarum Magistri Galteri . Medicinarum quedam sunt simplices
msItem.explicit: vii verso Hec de dosi medicinarum sufficiant
msItem.finalRubric: vii verso Explicit liber de dosibus medicinarum secundum Galterum Salernitanum Deo gracias

listBibl.bibl: See P. Pansier, Janus IX (1904), n. 21, for a list of other manuscripts that contain this text.

msItem.title: Note on suffering
msItem.incipit: vii verso Nota quod vi. sunt passiones
msItem.explicit: vii verso Vincencius de Sixino scripsit

msItem.title: Liber aggregationum [Latin] (tr. Simon of Genoa and Abraham of Tortosa)
msItem.author: Serapion the Younger (fl. 13th century)
msItem.incipit: 1r Postquam uidi librum Dyascoridis et librum Galeni in medicinis simplicibus aggregatos
msItem.finalRubric: 76r Explicit liber aggregationum Serapionis . In nomine domine amen

msItem.title: Two notes on the plant 'Satiryon'
msItem.incipit: 77v Nota hic secundum quod accepi de Diascoride de satyrion trifolia

msItem.title: De regimine sanitatis
msItem.incipit: 78r Secundum doctrinam sapiencium in arte medicine
msItem.finalRubric: 79v Explicit regimen sex rerum non naturaliam . Deo gracias amen
msItem.note: Title 'Tractatus de Regimine Sanitatis' added in the upper margin of f. 78r in the hand of Robert Marchall.

msItem.title: De simplicibus medicinis
msItem.author: Yuhanna ibn Masawaih (Mesue)
msItem.incipit: 80r In nomine Dei misericordis cuius tuitu sermo recipit graciam
msItem.note: Presented as two books, the second book begins on f. 88r with a list of capitula and the opening words: Protelauimus usque huc ..., ends abruptly in the chapter on the plant aristologia.

msItem.title: Areolae de conferentibus et nocentibus
msItem.author: Iohannes de Sancto Amando
msItem.rubric: 102r Incipit aureola medicinarum magistri Iohannis de Sancto Amando
msItem.incipit: 102r Sicut dicit Galen primo simplicis medicine capitulo 8 in fine Non est possibile ut homo accipiat medicinam
msItem.finalRubric: 120v Explicit liber S. M. Thadei Mesue
msItem.note: The 'Mesue' in the final rubric has been added in another hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: The recipe has the heading 'Preseruatiua regis Edwardi iiiite'. The scribe of the recipe has been identified as Thomas Deynman (fl. c. 1473, d. 1501), Bachelor of Medicine and Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. c. 1473, d. 1501 by R. M. Thomson, and Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall -1477 by Linda Voigts. Marchall was physician to Edward IV, and Deynman to Henry VII, but the hand of the recipe appears more like Deynman's than Marchall's; Marchall and Deynman knew each other, presumably through their Peterhouse connection and subsequent roles as royal physicians, and Deynman seems to have had access to several of Marchall's manuscripts (including this one) after Marchall's death in 1477, so it is not impossible for Deynman to have copied one of Marchall's recipes for Edward IV into one of Marchall's manuscripts.

listBibl.bibl: See T. Lang, 'Medical recipes from the Yorkist court', The Ricardian 20 (2010), pp. 94-102 for a discussion of similar recipes
R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Woodbridge, 2016), esp. p. 53

L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314, esp. pp. 276-277

p.secFol: ii recto: et amours est chose muable

signatures.p: Numeric leaf signatures in Roman numerals (i-ui) in the lower margin of Quire 2. These signatures are not present anywhere else in this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in the lower margin of the last verso of most quires, typically enclosed in a rectangular frame.

supportDesc.condition: Parchment trimmed for binding with minor losses to marginal annotations. Rodent and water damage to the upper margins of the leaves in the latter half of this Part, but no significant loss of text due to this damage. 12 leaves lost at the juncture between Quire 10 and 11, with three leaves lost from the end of Quire 10 and nine leaves lost from Quire 11; at least some of these leaves were probably text-leaves as the text at the end of f. 98v ends abruptly in the middle of a sentence.

p.seg: The leaves ff. i recto - iii verso are ruled frame only, and written in single-column format with an informal mise-en-page, 49-53 lines to the page, written below top line. It is possible that these leaves were once blank endleaves protecting a 'main text' starting on f. iv, but which were then subsequently used to record additional material.
The majority of this Part (ff. iv recto seq.,) is ruled in double-column format, frame and lines. Ruled in crayon, typically 65-70 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: The leaves ff. iv recto-120v are written in a southern European textualis rotunda by several different scribes who work in long stints and occasionally reappear throughout the manuscript.

decoNote.p: Coloured initials of the 'puzzle' type at major textual divisions.
Minor initials in red or blue in the 'Lombardic' style throughout this Part from f. iv recto onward.
Headings to chapters and minor divisions of the texts in red.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 2 - Guillame de Mandagout, De electionibus (glossed)

msItem.title: De electionibus (with Latin gloss) [Latin]
msItem.author: Guillaume de Mandagout (d. 1321)
msItem.incipit: 121r capitales propter quam uel quas non poterat absque periculo
msItem.note: Gloss incipit: 'In nomine domini amen etc tholose communionis . Nota quod locus est in procuratorio

collation.p: One quire of 8 leaves, the 8th leaf now the right pastedown.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Rodent and water damage to the upper margin, with slight loss of text. The final leaf of the quire was used as the right pastedown, and so the text on the verso of f. 128 cannot be read.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines, ruling very faint on some leaves. Ruled in double-column format, typically 40 lines to the column for the main text, and 60 lines to the column for the gloss; written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a southern European textualis rotunda.

decoNote.p: flourished initials in red and blue at the opening of each section of main text and gloss.
Important words, clauses, and headings underlined in red.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project
